EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

The Blythe Energy Project is owned by FPL Energy Operating Services, Inc, and located near the City of Blythe, Riverside County, California. The project site is located just west of the City of Blythe and directly adjacent to and east of the Blythe Airport (Figure 1). 

The Blythe Energy Project generates electricity from two high-efficiency, natural gas-fired turbines and one heat recovery steam generator.  The facility SIC code is 4911, and the NAICS code is 221119.  FPL Energy Operating Services is committed to safe, environmentally sensitive operation of the Blythe facility.  The Blythe Energy Project is operated in compliance with all federal, state, and local environmental and safety regulations.  Emergency response coordination procedures are in place with local emergency response agencies.  

Aqueous ammonia is the substance of interest for this document.  The covered process includes both the storage and use of aqueous ammonia.  Aqueous ammonia is used to reduce NOx (oxides of nitrogen) in the exhaust gas emissions through a Selective Catalytic Reduction (SCR) module or DeNOx system. The Blythe Energy Project is physically located in a sparsely populated, largely agricultural area west of the City of Blythe. The nearest areas normally used by the public include the airport to the west and a municipal golf course to the northeast. 

A key part of the RMP program is the process hazard analysis (PHA).  A PHA was performed for an aqueous ammonia storage and use process at another facility owned and operated by the parent company of Blythe Energy, LLC (FPL Energy).  That PHA, which is adopted for use at the Blythe facility, was performed using the Hazards and Operability Study (HazOp) procedure per OSHA guidelines and the guidelines published by the American Institute of Chemical Engineers.  The HazOp for aqueous ammonia concluded that potential deviations were of the ¿acceptable with appropriate controls¿ category or ¿acceptable as is¿ and id

entified appropriate response procedures to be used in the remote likelihood of their occurrence.  A supplemental ¿What If¿ analysis was also performed. 

An off-site consequence analysis was completed for the Blythe Energy Project during the Application for Certification (AFC) process during plant permitting with the California Energy Commission (CEC), and is used to address requirements found in the RMP regulation.  The off-site consequence analysis for the RMP addresses a worst-case release event that postulates the extremely improbable release of the entire contents of the largest storage tank on site.  We do not believe that such an event could reasonably be expected to occur; however, EPA requires us to evaluate this specific worst-case event.  The level of significance for the worst case event has been established by the EPA to be ¿ the 1 psi overpressure endpoint¿ ¿ in other words, the area within which the pressure is one pound per square inch greater that normal atmospheric pressure (about 14.7 psi). 

The distance to the endpoint of concern for the worst-case event is estimated to be 0.3 miles.  In other words, the area potentially significantly affected by such a worst-case release is limited to a radius less than 1/3 mile from the tank.  Within this radius, there are no public receptors of any kind.  Therefore, the worst-case release event, while extremely improbably, would none-the-less have no impact on the public.  

Blythe Energy Project has complied with the RMP requirements and is committed to review and enhance the program periodically as appropriate and in compliance with the program requirements. The RMP program documents are complete and accessible to all interested persons at all times.  We believe our program is proactive and not only meets regulatory requirements but also confirms our commitment to workplace safety as our number one priority. 

As a part of the preparation of the RMP program, Blythe Energy, LLC reviewed a hazards and operab

ility study (HAZOP) of an aqueous ammonia storage and distribution system for another plant owned by their parent company.  The Blythe Energy Project¿s SCR DeNOx (aqueous ammonia) system is very similar to the model that was reviewed. 

The objective of the HAZOP study is to identify potential hazards and their causes, consequences and appropriate mitigation responses or actions to counter the identified hazards. The HAZOP procedures performed at the other facility were adopted for use at the Blythe Energy Project.  On September 23, 2002, The Blythe Energy Production Team convened to perform a HAZOP study for the Blythe Power Project. This HAZOP study will be reviewed during the annual compliance audit. 

The worst-case release scenario(s) and the alternative release scenario(s)

The HazOp study reported in section 2.1 of this document shows that the only potentially significant AHM release would be from the ammonia storage and distribution system. The Most Likely Release was identified as a rupture of the distribution piping immediately downstream of the ammonia vaporizer (SCR skid). The release rate would be limited to the capacity of the vaporizer, 1,000 lb/hr. The rupture would cause audible alarms to sound in the facility's control room for ammonia flow and distribution pressure, and NOx emissions.  As a result, it is highly probable that the operators will shut down the ammonia release within 20 minutes.

There are no sensitive receptors within the immediate area surrounding the Blythe Energy Project. In particular, the nearest school is 4.5 miles east of the Blythe Energy facility.

Dispersion modeling was performed using the Area Location of Hazardous Atmospheres model (ALOHA, version 5.2); a program, developed by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (U.S. EPA) and the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA).  This model accepts surface meteorological data, including wind speed, direction, and temperature, and upper atmosphere inversion he

ight, for one hour. It determines whether a gas cloud with a density substantially greater than air will be formed, and uses either a Gaussian or dense gas algorithm, as appropriate, to determine AHM concentrations in the vicinity of the release point.  Unfortunately, the ALOHA program cannot directly model solutions which contain mixture such as aqueous ammonia (ammonia and water) because the ALOHA program assumes that the entire content of an aqueous ammonia release is anhydrous ammonia and the release behaves with the same physical properties as anhydrous ammonia.  Therefore, using conventional ALOHA program inputs would significantly over predict the threat zone of an aqueous ammonia spill.

NOAA Report No. HAZMAT 93-3, entitled ¿Modeling Hydrochloric Acid Evaporation in ALOHA¿, published by the Modeling and Simulation Studies Branch, Hazardous Material Response and Assessment Division, Office of Ocean Research Conservation and Assessment, developed a method for modeling mixed solutions such as aqueous ammonia.  The modeling method used in this report is based on determining evaporation rates of low flashpoint materials in solution from a liquid pool.  The evaporation formula in the report is based on pool area, low flashpoint material mass transfer rates, and molecular weight of the material flashing, vapor pressure of the material, gas constant, and ambient temperature.  Once the evaporation rate is established, conventional inputs to the ALOHA program can be used to determine the maximum threat zones.

The evaporation rate of aqueous ammonia from a tank release in the secondary containment area proposed for the Blythe Energy Project was calculated to be 0.127 kg/s (kilogram per second), at an ambient temperature of 100°F and wind speed of 1 m/s (meter per second).  This was assumed to be the worst-case release scenario.  Worst-case meteorological conditions for the modeling were assumed to be F stability class, wind speed of 1 m/s, and ambient temperatures of

100°F.  At concentrations of 75, 200, 300, 500, 1,000, and 2,000 ppm levels of the airborne ammonia, the ALOHA model predicted maximum threat zones of 0.86, 0.48, 0.39, 0.29, 0.20, and 0.14 miles, respectively.  These results are provided in Attachment C, along with manual calculations for the evaporation rate determination.

The scenario was also run for stability class D at a wind speed of 5.0 m/s and ambient temperature of 100°F.  This weather condition represents the likely actual meteorological condition at the Blythe Energy power plant site.  The hand calculated evaporation rate for this condition was determined to be 0.445 kg/s.  The ALOHA program predicted maximum threat zones of 0.24 miles for 75 ppm, 0.14 for 200 ppm, 0.11 miles for 300 ppm, 0.09 miles for 500 ppm, 0.06 miles for 1,000 ppm, and 0.04 for 2,000 ppm concentrations of ammonia.  

When comparing stability class F to stability class D modeling results, a significant reduction occurs in the maximum threat zone.  Therefore, the stability class F can be considered the absolute worst-case modeling scenario for a release from the aqueous ammonia storage tanks at the Blythe Energy power plant.

The nearest residential dwelling from the release point is approximately 0.75 miles.  The nearest likely area with contact to a spill from this area is Hobsonway, 0.43 miles from the aqueous ammonia storage area.  This road, however, is not frequently traveled.  At F stability, only concentrations of 75-ppm ammonia could reach the residential dwelling, and only concentrations of 200 ppm or lower of ammonia could reach Hobsonway.  None of the D stability class results reached the nearest residential dwelling or Hobsonway.  Therefore, potential nearby exposure areas are well below the 300 ppm IDLH (immediate dangerous to life and health) concentration.

The general accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps

Although the Blythe Energy Project is not subject to PSM regulations, t

he facility and its management subscribe to the safe practices outlined in the OSHA 29 CFR 1910.119 program, namely, those programs which ensure:
¿	Employees are adequately trained,
¿	Equipment mechanical integrity,
¿	Safe management of change,
¿	Equipment/instrument designs that minimize incident potential,
¿	Incident investigations generate corrective actions to minimize recurrence, and
¿	Operating procedures are relevant and minimize the risk of incidents

The five-year accident history

This is a new facility and as such does not have an accident history.  We are not aware of significant incidents involving similar facilities from which this facility was designed.

The emergency response program

The plant has a current ¿Emergency Action Plan¿ in accordance with 29 CFR 1910.38(a) (Action Plans).  Employees have been trained in the plan and the plan is reviewed frequently to verify that it is current with plant operating practice.  Additionally, the facility has developed a procedures which include actions necessary for controlling incidental releases of hazardous materials including those designated as highly hazardous chemicals by 29 CFR 1910.119. Additionally, emergency response procedures are included with the required Hazardous Materials Business Plan, submitted to the local Riverside County Environmental Health Department with a copy to all emergency response agencies.  Copies of the appropriate emergency procedures available in the administration building and the manned control rooms.   

Planned changes to improve safety

This is a new facility and it has been designed and built using ¿state-of-the-art¿ engineering and safety technology.  Prior to plant startup, a pre-startup safety review (PSSR) will be conducted and last minute design changes will be made based on the findings of the PSSR.  All changes to the plant are subject to the facility ¿Management of Change¿ (MOC) procedure which ensures a thorough review of all environment, health and safety iss

ues to maintain expected safety performance.

Periodic environment, health, and safety audits are used to gather sufficient facts and information to verify compliance with standards and to determine what changes could be made to improve safety. The plant's General Manager is responsible for ensuring that these periodic audits are performed.  The audits includes an evaluation of the design and effectiveness of the process safety management system and a field inspection of the safety and health conditions and practices to verify that the systems are being effectively implemented. Audits are conducted or led by a person knowledgeable in audit techniques. The essential elements of the audit program include planning, staffing, conducting the audit, evaluating hazards and deficiencies and taking corrective action, performing follow up and documenting actions.

Audits are performed to verify that the procedures and practices developed in this RMP Manual are adequate and are being followed.  The purpose of these audits is to educate employees on the appropriate method to apply the RMP plan, and not to take disciplinary actions.  The process and its operations being audited relate only to the aqueous ammonia systems.  Audits includes a review of the RMP Manual, inspection of the physical facilities, and interviews with all levels of plant personnel.  A checklist that details the requirements of each section of the standard is used during the audit. 
Through interviews, the auditor evaluates employees' knowledge and awareness of the safety procedures, duties, rules, and emergency response assignments. During the inspection, the auditor notes actual practices such as safety and health policies, procedures, and work authorization procedures. This approach enables the auditor to identify deficiencies and determine where corrective actions or improvements are necessary.  
Periodic audits, operating procedures are reviewed periodically using a ¿job safety analysis¿ (JSA) process.

The JSA examines procedures through actual observation while the procedures are being performed.  Procedures are modified as necessary to improve environment, health and safety performance.  JSAs along with daily inspections by supervision are used to specify training needs and these needs are used to develop training programs.

In addition, any incidents that may occur are fully investigated to determine the root cause(s) and for developing corrective actions to minimize recurrence.


Blythe Energy, LLC prepared this RMP program document in conjunction with our consultants and vendors.
